intro: Phymatis cyminoides, commonly known as the Persian cumin or wild cumin, is a flowering plant native to the Middle East and Central Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic compounds and compound umbels of small white or greenish flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in steppe and desert environments. Its seeds are used in traditional medicine and as a spice, similar to cumin. The leaves and stems are also used in local cuisines for their distinct flavor.
